docs.lead_paragraph: The debate before the Supreme Court today was over welfare policy -- whether states can have a lower level of benefits for newcomers than for longtime residents -- but the deeper issue was the meaning of citizenship. California was asking the Court to permit it to do what Congress authorized in the 1996 welfare law: hold newcomers, for their first year of residency, to the welfare benefits they would have received in their home state, often hundreds of dollars a month lower.
docs.abstract: Supreme Court hears debate over California's request to hold newcomers to welfare benefits they would have received in their home state; Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg says Court precedents on right to travel seem to indicate that new residents and longtime residents are entitled to equal treatment; Constitution does not mention right to travel, but decisions in 1960's derive it from guarantee of equal protection (M)
docs.snippet: The debate before the Supreme Court today was over welfare policy -- whether states can have a lower level of benefits for newcomers than for longtime residents -- but the deeper issue was the meaning of citizenship.    California was asking the...

docs.lead_paragraph: When my twin sons were born 29 years ago, fetal monitoring was not a routine part of labor and delivery, and there was no way to be certain the babies were doing O.K. while my uterus tried in vain to expel them. So when the doctor announced after many anxious hours of unproductive labor that he was going to have to deliver them by Caesarean, my response was, ''I don't care if I cough them up as long as they're alive and healthy.''

headline.main: A Saner Approach On Caesarean Issue

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on Caesarean deliveries, noting they have become far more common than formerly and that saner attitudes about Caesarian section are prevailing; table shows medical conditions that most commonly result in Caesarean deliveries (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: In mythology, fire-breathing monsters with lions' heads, goats' bodies and serpents' tails are well-known chimeras. In humans, chimeras form when cells from two people live side by side in one person, during and after such diverse events as pregnancy, organ transplantation and blood transfusion.

headline.main: Keeping Harmony in the Marriage of Cells

docs.abstract: Lawrence K Altman reports on chimeras that form in humans when cells from two people live side by side in one person, during and after such diverse events as pregnancy, organ transplantation and blood transfusion; Dr Selim Aractingi in Paris and his team may have solved mystery of why many women itch from a rash in last weeks of pregnancy; rash apparently is caused by fetal cells that escape from mother's womb and lodge in skin; it is newest evidence of chimerism's role in human disorders; last year, Dr J Lee Nelson and her colleagues at Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center in Seattle reported first evidence linking cells that escaped from fetus into mother's bloodstream to development of a disease in mother years after pregnancy; disease--known as scleroderma, affects skin and other organs; photo of mythical Chimera of Arezzo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''4 Childbirth Specialists Challenge U.S. Goal of Reducing Caesarean Births'' (news article, Jan. 7): The four doctors mentioned in your article fall into the same trap as those they criticize. By setting ''what the rate should be for given conditions . . . [such as] diabetes in the mother,'' Dr. Frederic Frigoletto will perpetuate the very problem he is complaining about. Every woman differs from all others, every pregnancy differs from all others, and every labor differs from all others.
docs.abstract: Dr David H Fields letter says only rational way to decide if Caesarean section is appropriate is to look at particular circumstances of each pregnant woman (Jan 7 article)

docs.lead_paragraph: Five months pregnant, her belly just beginning to show through the orange prison jumpsuit, Karen Ptaschnik has become an unlikely lightning rod for the abortion debate here. Ms. Ptaschnik, a 30-year-old single mother of three young children, is serving a 15-to-24-month sentence in the Luzerne County jail for selling cocaine and driving with a suspended license. This fall, when she told the prison authorities that she was pregnant and wanted an abortion, they said no.

headline.main: A Prisoner Is the Focus of an Abortion Debate

docs.abstract: Karen Ptaschnik, who is serving jail sentence on drug charges, has become unlikely lightning rod for abortion debate in staunchly Catholic Luzerne County, Pa; Ptaschnik's request for abortion was denied by prison authorities, even when she volunteered to pay for it herself; with help of abortion-rights lawyers, matter went to Federal judge, who said county must pay for her abortion; Ptaschnik opted not to have abortion, because legal victory did not come until she was already in fifth month of pregnancy; she claims she and her children are suffering harassment and verbal abuse because of matter; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The most intriguing thing about ''Some Voices'' is a mushroom omelet. It's prepared onstage by Max Baker at the conclusion of the two-hour play, and the actor makes such a pleasant production of the chopping, sauteeing and whisking that you find yourself more engrossed in his labors than in virtually anything else that happens all evening. The cooking eggs give off the aroma of authenticity, which otherwise is missing much of the time in the New Group staging of Joe Penhall's play about a high-spirited, mentally ill young man fighting his biochemical impulses for a life of some emotional suppleness.

headline.main: Fluffy Eggs and a Haze of Medication

docs.abstract: Peter Marks reviews Some Voices, Joe Penhall play directed by Frank Pugliese for New Group; photo (S)
